title: 113_hr5806
content: The Act may be cited as the "Supporting America's Charities Act" and includes a special rule for qualified conservation contributions that is modified and made permanent. The "Supporting America's Charities Act" makes permanent amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding qualified conservation contributions by individuals and corporations. The "Supporting America's Charities Act" allows contributions of property made by a Native Corporation under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act to be deductible, limited by the taxpayer's taxable income. Excess contributions can be carried over for future deductions. The "Supporting America's Charities Act" allows excess contributions by a Native Corporation to be treated as charitable contributions over 15 years. A conforming amendment expands the applicability of the deduction. Valid existing rights are preserved. The amendments made by the "Supporting America's Charities Act" preserve valid property rights of Native Corporations under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. The effective date for these changes is after December 31, 2013. Extension and expansion of charitable deduction for contributions of food inventory. Extension and expansion of charitable deduction for contributions of food inventory. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to remove certain clauses and increase the limitation on contributions that can be taken into account for tax purposes. The aggregate amount of contributions for any taxable year is limited to 15 percent of the taxpayer's aggregate net income from all trades or businesses. The charitable deduction for contributions of food inventory is extended and expanded under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The limitation on contributions is increased to 15 percent of the taxpayer's aggregate net income from all trades or businesses. If the aggregate amount exceeds this limitation, the excess is treated as a charitable contribution. The charitable contribution described allows for donations to be spread over 5 years. The overall corporate limitation does not apply to these contributions, but the limitation is reduced by the aggregate amount of such contributions. The taxpayer may elect to treat the basis of any contributions as allowable under subsection (b)(2)(A) if certain conditions are met. The taxpayer can elect to treat the basis of apparently wholesome food contributions as 25 percent of their fair market value. Fair market value determination is specified for food contributions that cannot be sold due to internal standards, lack of market, or being produced exclusively for transfer purposes. For food contributions transferred to a described organization, the fair market value is determined without considering internal standards, lack of market, or exclusive purpose. It is based on the price at which similar food items are sold by the taxpayer at the time of contribution. The amendments made by this section apply to contributions made after December 31, 2013, in taxable years ending after that date. Contributions made by c corporations in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2013, are also affected. SEC. 4 amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow tax-free distributions from individual retirement accounts for charitable purposes permanently. SEC. 5 states that the budgetary effects of this Act will not be entered on PAYGO scorecards.
